6.verse: and there at the bronze altar, Solomon offered a thousand animals as sacrifices to please the LORD.

7.verse: God appeared to Solomon that night in a dream and said, “Solomon, ask for anything you want, and I will give it to you.”

8.verse: Solomon answered: LORD God, you were always loyal to my father David, and now you have made me king of Israel.

9.verse: I am supposed to rule these people, but there are as many of them as there are specks of dust on the ground. So keep the promise you made to my father

10.verse: and make me wise. Give me the knowledge I’ll need to be the king of this great nation of yours.

11.verse: God replied: Solomon, you could have asked me to make you rich or famous or to let you live a long time. Or you could have asked for your enemies to be destroyed. Instead, you asked for wisdom and knowledge to rule my people.

12.verse: So I will make you wise and intelligent. But I will also make you richer and more famous than any king before or after you.

13.verse: Solomon then left Gibeon and returned to Jerusalem, the capital city of Israel.

14.verse: Solomon’s Wealth - Solomon had a force of one thousand four hundred chariots and twelve thousand horses that he kept in Jerusalem and other towns.

15.verse: While Solomon was king of Israel, there was silver and gold everywhere in Jerusalem, and cedar was as common as ordinary sycamore trees in the foothills.

16.verse: Solomon’s merchants bought his horses and chariots in the regions of Musri and Kue. They paid about fifteen pounds of silver for a chariot and almost four pounds of silver for a horse. They also sold horses and chariots to the Hittite and Syrian kings.

17.verse: Solomon’s merchants bought his horses and chariots in the regions of Musri and Kue. They paid about fifteen pounds of silver for a chariot and almost four pounds of silver for a horse. They also sold horses and chariots to the Hittite and Syrian kings.

1.verse: Solomon Asks Hiram To Help Build the Temple - Solomon decided to build a temple where the LORD would be worshiped, and also to build a palace for himself.

2.verse: He assigned seventy thousand men to carry building supplies and eighty thousand to cut stone from the hills. And he chose three thousand six hundred men to supervise these workers.

3.verse: Solomon sent the following message to King Hiram of Tyre: Years ago, when my father David was building his palace, you supplied him with cedar logs. Now will you send me supplies?

4.verse: I am building a temple where the LORD my God will be worshiped. Sweet-smelling incense will be burned there, and sacred bread will be offered to him. Worshipers will offer sacrifices to the LORD every morning and evening, every Sabbath, and on the first day of each month, as well as during all our religious festivals. These things will be done for all time, just as the LORD has commanded.

5.verse: This will be a great temple, because our God is greater than all other gods.

6.verse: No one can ever build a temple large enough for God—even the heavens are too small a place for him to live in! All I can do is build a place where we can offer sacrifices to him.

7.verse: Send me a worker who can not only carve, but who can work with gold, silver, bronze, and iron, as well as make brightly colored cloth. The person you send will work here in Judah and Jerusalem with the skilled workers that my father has already hired.

8.verse: I know that you have workers who are experts at cutting lumber in Lebanon. So would you please send me some cedar, pine, and juniper logs? My workers will be there to help them,

9.verse: because I’ll need a lot of lumber to build such a large and glorious temple.

10.verse: I will pay your woodcutters one hundred twenty-five thousand bushels of wheat, the same amount of barley, one hundred fifteen thousand gallons of wine, and that same amount of olive oil.

11.verse: Hiram sent his answer back to Solomon: I know that the LORD must love his people, because he has chosen you to be their king.

12.verse: Praise the LORD God of Israel who made heaven and earth! He has given David a son who isn’t only wise and smart, but who has the knowledge to build a temple for the LORD and a palace for himself.

13.verse: I am sending Huram Abi to you. He is very bright.

14.verse: His mother was from the Israelite tribe of Dan, and his father was from Tyre. Not only is Huram an expert at working with gold, silver, bronze, iron, stone, and wood, but he can also make colored cloth and fine linen. And he can carve anything if you give him a pattern to follow. He can help your workers and those hired by your father King David.

15.verse: Go ahead and send the wheat, barley, olive oil, and wine you promised to pay my workers.

16.verse: I will tell them to start cutting down trees in Lebanon. They will cut as many as you need, then tie them together into rafts, and float them down along the coast to Joppa. Your workers can take them to Jerusalem from there.

17.verse: Solomon’s Work Force - Solomon counted all the foreigners who were living in Israel, just as his father David had done when he was king, and the total was 153,600.

18.verse: He assigned 70,000 of them to carry building supplies and 80,000 of them to cut stone from the hills. He chose 3,600 others to supervise the workers and to make sure the work was completed.

1.verse: The Temple Is Built - Solomon’s workers began building the temple in Jerusalem on the second day of the second month, four years after Solomon had become king of Israel. It was built on Mount Moriah where the LORD had appeared to David at the threshing place that had belonged to Araunah from Jebus.

2.verse: The Temple Is Built - Solomon’s workers began building the temple in Jerusalem on the second day of the second month, four years after Solomon had become king of Israel. It was built on Mount Moriah where the LORD had appeared to David at the threshing place that had belonged to Araunah from Jebus.

3.verse: The inside of the temple was ninety feet long and thirty feet wide, according to the older standards.

4.verse: Across the front of the temple was a porch thirty feet wide and thirty feet high. The inside walls of the porch were covered with pure gold.

5.verse: Solomon had the inside walls of the temple’s main room paneled first with pine and then with a layer of gold, and he had them decorated with carvings of palm trees and designs that looked like chains.

6.verse: He used precious stones to decorate the temple, and he used gold imported from Parvaim

7.verse: to decorate the ceiling beams, the doors, the door frames, and the walls. Solomon also had the workers carve designs of winged creatures into the walls.

8.verse: The most holy place was thirty feet square, and its walls were covered with almost twenty-five tons of fine gold.

9.verse: More than a pound of gold was used to cover the heads of the nails. The walls of the small storage rooms were also covered with gold.

10.verse: Solomon had two statues of winged creatures made to put in the most holy place, and he covered them with gold.

11.verse: Each creature had two wings and was fifteen feet from the tip of one wing to the tip of the other wing. Solomon set them next to each other in the most holy place, facing the doorway. Their wings were spread out and reached all the way across the thirty foot room.

12.verse: Each creature had two wings and was fifteen feet from the tip of one wing to the tip of the other wing. Solomon set them next to each other in the most holy place, facing the doorway. Their wings were spread out and reached all the way across the thirty foot room.

13.verse: Each creature had two wings and was fifteen feet from the tip of one wing to the tip of the other wing. Solomon set them next to each other in the most holy place, facing the doorway. Their wings were spread out and reached all the way across the thirty foot room.

14.verse: A curtain was made of fine linen woven with blue, purple, and red wool, and embroidered with designs of winged creatures.

15.verse: The Two Columns - Two columns were made for the entrance to the temple. Each one was fifty-two feet tall and had a cap on top that was seven and a half feet high.

16.verse: The top of each column was decorated with designs that looked like chains and with a hundred carvings of pomegranates.

17.verse: Solomon had one of the columns placed on the south side of the temple’s entrance; it was called Jachin. The other one was placed on the north side of the entrance; it was called Boaz.

1.verse: The Furnishings for the Temple - Solomon had a bronze altar made that was thirty feet square and fifteen feet high.

2.verse: He also gave orders to make a large metal bowl called the Sea. It was fifteen feet across, about seven and a half feet deep, and forty-five feet around.

3.verse: Its outer edge was decorated with two rows of carvings of bulls, ten bulls to every eighteen inches, all made from the same piece of metal as the bowl.

4.verse: The bowl itself sat on top of twelve bronze bulls, with three bulls facing outward in each of four directions.

5.verse: The sides of the bowl were four inches thick, and its rim was in the shape of a cup that curved outward like flower petals. The bowl held about fifteen thousand gallons.

6.verse: He also made ten small bowls and put five on each side of the large bowl. The small bowls were used to wash the animals that were burned on the altar as sacrifices, and the priests used the water in the large bowl to wash their hands.

7.verse: Ten gold lampstands were also made according to the plans. Solomon placed these lampstands inside the temple, five on each side of the main room.

8.verse: He also made ten tables and placed them in the main room, five on each side. And he made a hundred small gold sprinkling bowls.

9.verse: Solomon gave orders to build two courtyards: a smaller one that only priests could use and a larger one. The doors to these courtyards were covered with bronze.

10.verse: The large bowl called the Sea was placed near the southeast corner of the temple.

11.verse: Huram made shovels, sprinkling bowls, and pans for hot ashes. Here is a list of the other furnishings he made for God’s temple:

12.verse: two columns, two bowl-shaped caps for the tops of these columns, two chain designs on the caps,

13.verse: four hundred pomegranates for the chain designs,

14.verse: the stands and the small bowls,

15.verse: the large bowl and the twelve bulls that held it up,

16.verse: pans for hot ashes, as well as shovels and meat forks. Huram made all these things out of polished bronze

17.verse: by pouring melted bronze into the clay molds he had set up near the Jordan River, between Succoth and Zeredah.

18.verse: There were so many bronze furnishings that no one ever knew how much bronze it took to make them.

19.verse: Solomon also gave orders to make the following temple furnishings out of gold: the altar, the tables that held the sacred loaves of bread,

20.verse: the lampstands and the lamps that burned in front of the most holy place,

21.verse: flower designs, lamps and tongs,

22.verse: lamp snuffers, small sprinkling bowls, ladles, fire pans, and the doors to the most holy place and the main room of the temple.

1.verse: After the LORD’s temple was finished, Solomon put in its storage rooms everything that his father David had dedicated to the LORD, including the gold and silver, and the objects used in worship.

2.verse: Solomon Brings the Sacred Chest to the Temple - The sacred chest had been kept on Mount Zion, also known as the city of David. But Solomon decided to have the chest moved to the temple while everyone was in Jerusalem to celebrate the Festival of Shelters during the seventh month. Solomon called together all the important leaders of Israel.

3.verse: Solomon Brings the Sacred Chest to the Temple - The sacred chest had been kept on Mount Zion, also known as the city of David. But Solomon decided to have the chest moved to the temple while everyone was in Jerusalem to celebrate the Festival of Shelters during the seventh month. Solomon called together all the important leaders of Israel.

4.verse: Then the priests and the Levites picked up the sacred chest, the sacred tent, and the objects used for worship, and they carried them to the temple.

5.verse: Then the priests and the Levites picked up the sacred chest, the sacred tent, and the objects used for worship, and they carried them to the temple.

6.verse: Solomon and a crowd of people walked in front of the chest, and along the way they sacrificed more sheep and cattle than could be counted.

7.verse: The priests carried the chest into the most holy place and put it under the winged creatures,

8.verse: whose wings covered the chest and the poles used for carrying it.

9.verse: The poles were so long that they could be seen from just outside the most holy place, but not from anywhere else. And they stayed there from then on.

10.verse: The only things kept in the chest were the two flat stones Moses had put there when the LORD made his agreement with the people of Israel at Mount Sinai, after bringing them out of Egypt.

11.verse: The priests of every group had gone through the ceremony to make themselves clean and acceptable to the LORD. The Levite musicians, including Asaph, Heman, Jeduthun, and their sons and relatives, were wearing robes of fine linen. They were standing on the east side of the altar, playing cymbals, small harps, and other stringed instruments. One hundred twenty priests were with these musicians, and they were blowing trumpets. They were praising the LORD by playing music and singing: “The LORD is good, and his love never ends.” Suddenly a cloud filled the temple as the priests were leaving the holy place.

14.verse: The LORD’s glory was in that cloud, and the light from it was so bright that the priests could not stay inside to do their work.

1.verse: Solomon prayed: “Our LORD, you said that you would live in a dark cloud.

2.verse: Now I’ve built a glorious temple where you can live forever.”

3.verse: Solomon Speaks to the People - Solomon turned toward the people standing there. Then he blessed them

4.verse: and said: Praise the LORD God of Israel! He brought his people out of Egypt long ago and later kept his promise to make my father David the king of Israel. The LORD also promised him that Jerusalem would be the city where his temple will be built, and now that promise has come true.

5.verse: and said: Praise the LORD God of Israel! He brought his people out of Egypt long ago and later kept his promise to make my father David the king of Israel. The LORD also promised him that Jerusalem would be the city where his temple will be built, and now that promise has come true.

6.verse: and said: Praise the LORD God of Israel! He brought his people out of Egypt long ago and later kept his promise to make my father David the king of Israel. The LORD also promised him that Jerusalem would be the city where his temple will be built, and now that promise has come true.

7.verse: When my father wanted to build a temple for the LORD God of Israel,

8.verse: the LORD said, “It’s good that you want to build a temple where I can be worshiped.

9.verse: But you’re not the one to do it. Your son will build the temple to honor me.”

10.verse: The LORD has done what he promised. I am now the king of Israel, and I’ve built a temple for the LORD our God.

11.verse: I’ve also put the sacred chest in the temple. And in that chest are the two flat stones on which is written the solemn agreement the LORD made with our ancestors when he rescued them from Egypt.

12.verse: Solomon Prays at the Temple - Earlier, Solomon had a bronze platform made that was about eight feet square and five feet high, and he put it in the center of the outer courtyard near the altar. Solomon stood on the platform facing the altar with everyone standing behind him. Then he lifted his arms toward heaven; he knelt down

13.verse: Solomon Prays at the Temple - Earlier, Solomon had a bronze platform made that was about eight feet square and five feet high, and he put it in the center of the outer courtyard near the altar. Solomon stood on the platform facing the altar with everyone standing behind him. Then he lifted his arms toward heaven; he knelt down

14.verse: and prayed: LORD God of Israel, no other god in heaven or on earth is like you! You never forget the agreement you made with your people, and you are loyal to anyone who faithfully obeys your teachings.

15.verse: My father David was your servant, and today you have kept every promise you made to him.

16.verse: You promised that someone from his family would always be king of Israel, if they do their best to obey you, just as he did.

17.verse: Please keep this promise you made to your servant David.

18.verse: There’s not enough room in all of heaven for you, LORD God. How could you possibly live on earth in this temple I have built?

19.verse: But I ask you to answer my prayer.

20.verse: This is the temple where you have chosen to be worshiped. Please watch over it day and night and listen when I turn toward it and pray.

21.verse: I am your servant, and the people of Israel belong to you, and so whenever any of us look toward this temple and pray, answer from your home in heaven and forgive our sins.

22.verse: Suppose someone accuses a person of a crime, and the accused has to stand in front of the altar in your temple and say, “I swear I am innocent!”

23.verse: Listen from heaven and decide who is right. Then punish the guilty person and let the innocent one go free.

24.verse: Suppose your people Israel sin against you, and then an enemy defeats them. If they come to this temple and beg for forgiveness,

25.verse: listen from your home in heaven. Forgive them and bring them back to the land you gave their ancestors.

26.verse: Suppose your people sin against you, and you punish them by holding back the rain. If they stop sinning and turn toward this temple to pray in your name,

27.verse: listen from your home in heaven and forgive them. The people of Israel are your servants, so teach them to live right. And send rain on the land you promised them forever.

28.verse: Sometimes the crops may dry up or rot or be eaten by locusts or grasshoppers, and your people will be starving. Sometimes enemies may surround their towns, or your people will become sick with deadly diseases.

29.verse: Please listen when anyone in Israel truly feels sorry and sincerely prays with arms lifted toward your temple.

30.verse: You know what is in everyone’s heart. So from your home in heaven answer their prayers, according to what they do and what is in their hearts.

31.verse: Then your people will worship you and obey you for as long as they live in the land you gave their ancestors.

32.verse: Foreigners will hear about you and your mighty power, and some of them will come to live among your people Israel. If any of them pray toward this temple,

33.verse: listen from your home in heaven and answer their prayers. Then everyone on earth will worship you, just as your own people Israel do, and they will know that I have built this temple in your honor.

34.verse: Sometimes you will order your people to attack their enemies. Then your people will turn toward this temple I have built for you in your chosen city, and they will pray to you.

35.verse: Answer their prayers from heaven and give them victory.

36.verse: Everyone sins. But when your people sin against you, suppose you get angry enough to let their enemies drag them away to foreign countries.

37.verse: Later, they may feel sorry for what they did and ask your forgiveness. Answer them when they pray toward this temple I have built for you in your chosen city, here in this land you gave their ancestors. From your home in heaven, listen to their sincere prayers and forgive your people who have sinned against you.

38.verse: Later, they may feel sorry for what they did and ask your forgiveness. Answer them when they pray toward this temple I have built for you in your chosen city, here in this land you gave their ancestors. From your home in heaven, listen to their sincere prayers and forgive your people who have sinned against you.

39.verse: Later, they may feel sorry for what they did and ask your forgiveness. Answer them when they pray toward this temple I have built for you in your chosen city, here in this land you gave their ancestors. From your home in heaven, listen to their sincere prayers and forgive your people who have sinned against you.

40.verse: LORD God, hear us when we pray in this temple.

41.verse: Come to your new home, where we have already placed the sacred chest, which is the symbol of your strength. I pray that when the priests announce your power to save people, those who are faithful to you will celebrate what you’ve done for them.

42.verse: Always remember the love you had for your servant David, so that you will not reject your chosen kings.

1.verse: Solomon Dedicates the Temple - As soon as Solomon finished praying, fire came down from heaven and burned up the offerings. The LORD’s dazzling glory then filled the temple,

2.verse: and the priests could not go in.

3.verse: When the crowd of people saw the fire and the LORD’s glory, they knelt down and worshiped the LORD. They prayed: “The LORD is good, and his love never ends.”

4.verse: Solomon and the people dedicated the temple to the LORD by sacrificing twenty-two thousand cattle and one hundred twenty thousand sheep.

5.verse: Solomon and the people dedicated the temple to the LORD by sacrificing twenty-two thousand cattle and one hundred twenty thousand sheep.

6.verse: Everybody stood up during the ceremony. The priests were in their assigned places, blowing their trumpets. And the Levites faced them, playing the musical instruments that David had made for them to use when they praised the LORD for his never-ending love.

7.verse: On that same day, Solomon dedicated the courtyard in front of the temple and got it ready to be used for worship. The bronze altar he had made was too small, so he used the courtyard to offer sacrifices to please the LORD and grain sacrifices, and also to send up in smoke the fat from the other offerings.

8.verse: For seven days, Solomon and the crowd celebrated the Festival of Shelters, and people came from as far away as the Egyptian Gorge in the south and Lebo-Hamath in the north.

9.verse: Then on the next day, everyone came together for worship. They had celebrated a total of fourteen days, seven days for the dedication of the altar and seven more days for the festival.

10.verse: Then on the twenty-third day of the seventh month, Solomon sent everyone home. They left very happy because of all the good things the LORD had done for David and Solomon, and for his people Israel.

11.verse: The LORD Appears to Solomon Again - The LORD’s temple and Solomon’s palace were now finished. In fact, everything Solomon had planned to do was completed.

12.verse: Some time later, the LORD appeared to Solomon in a dream and said: I heard your prayer, and I have chosen this temple as the place where sacrifices will be offered to me.

13.verse: Suppose I hold back the rain or send locusts to eat the crops or make my people suffer with deadly diseases.

14.verse: If my own people will humbly pray and turn back to me and stop sinning, then I will answer them from heaven. I will forgive them and make their land fertile once again.

15.verse: I will hear the prayers made in this temple,

16.verse: because it belongs to me, and this is where I will be worshiped forever. I will never stop watching over it.

17.verse: Your father David obeyed me, and now, Solomon, you must do the same. Obey my laws and teachings,

18.verse: and I will keep my solemn promise to him that someone from your family will always be king of Israel.

19.verse: But if you or any of the people of Israel disobey my laws or start worshiping foreign gods,

20.verse: I will pull you out of this land I gave you. I will desert this temple where I said I would be worshiped, so that people everywhere will think it is only a joke and will make fun of it.

21.verse: This temple is now magnificent. But when these things happen, everyone who walks by it will be shocked and will ask, “Why did the LORD do such a terrible thing to his people and to this temple?”

22.verse: Then they will answer, “It was because the people of Israel rejected the LORD their God, who rescued their ancestors from Egypt, and they started worshiping other gods.”

1.verse: Other Things Solomon Did - It took twenty years for the LORD’s temple and Solomon’s palace to be built.

2.verse: After that, Solomon had his workers rebuild the towns that Hiram had given him. Then Solomon sent Israelites to live in those towns.

3.verse: Solomon attacked and captured the town of Hamath-Zobah.

4.verse: He had his workers build the town of Tadmor in the desert and some towns in Hamath where he could keep his supplies.

5.verse: He strengthened Upper Beth-Horon and Lower Beth-Horon by adding walls and gates that could be locked.

6.verse: He did the same thing to the town of Baalath and to the cities where he kept supplies, chariots, and horses. Solomon had his workers build whatever he wanted in Jerusalem, Lebanon, and anywhere else in his kingdom.

7.verse: Solomon did not force the Israelites to do his work. Instead, they were his soldiers, officers, army commanders, and cavalry troops. But he did make slaves of the Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites who were living in Israel. These were the descendants of those foreigners the Israelites did not destroy, and they remained Israel’s slaves.

But he did make slaves of the Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites who were living in Israel. But he did make slaves of the Hittites, Amorites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites who were living in Israel. These were the descendants of those foreigners the Israelites did not destroy, and they remained Israel’s slaves.

10.verse: Solomon appointed two hundred fifty officers to be in charge of his workers.

11.verse: Solomon’s wife, the daughter of the king of Egypt, moved from the part of Jerusalem called David’s City to her new palace that Solomon had built. The sacred chest had been kept in David’s City, which made his palace sacred, and so Solomon’s wife could no longer live there.

12.verse: Solomon offered sacrifices to the LORD on the altar he had built in front of the temple.

13.verse: He followed the requirements that Moses had given for sacrifices offered on the Sabbath, on the first day of each month, the Festival of Thin Bread, the Harvest Festival, and the Festival of Shelters.

14.verse: Solomon then assigned the priests and the Levites their duties at the temple, and he followed the instructions that his father David had given him. Some of the Levites were to lead music and help the priests in their duties, and others were to guard the temple gates

15.verse: and the storage rooms. The priests and Levites followed these instructions exactly.

16.verse: Everything Solomon had planned to do was now finished—from the laying of the temple’s foundation to its completion.

17.verse: Solomon went to Ezion-Geber and Eloth, two Edomite towns on the Red Sea.

18.verse: Hiram sent him ships and some of his experienced sailors. They went with Solomon’s own sailors to the country of Ophir and brought back about seventeen tons of gold for Solomon.

1.verse: The Queen of Sheba Visits Solomon - The Queen of Sheba heard how famous Solomon was, so she went to Jerusalem to test him with difficult questions. She took along several of her officials, and she loaded her camels with gifts of spices, jewels, and gold. When she arrived, she and Solomon talked about everything she could think of.

2.verse: He answered every question, no matter how difficult it was.

3.verse: The Queen was amazed at Solomon’s wisdom. She was breathless when she saw his palace, the food on his table, his officials, all his servants in their uniforms, and the sacrifices he offered at the LORD’s temple.

4.verse: The Queen was amazed at Solomon’s wisdom. She was breathless when she saw his palace, the food on his table, his officials, all his servants in their uniforms, and the sacrifices he offered at the LORD’s temple.

5.verse: She said: Solomon, in my own country I had heard about your wisdom and all you’ve done.

6.verse: But I didn’t believe it until I saw it with my own eyes! And there’s so much I didn’t hear about. You are greater than I was told.

7.verse: Your people and officials are lucky to be here where they can listen to the wise things you say.

8.verse: I praise the LORD your God. He is pleased with you and has made you king of Israel. God loves the people of this country and will never desert them, so he has given them a king who will rule fairly and honestly.

9.verse: The Queen of Sheba gave Solomon almost five tons of gold, a large amount of jewels, and the best spices anyone had ever seen.

10.verse: In return, Solomon gave her everything she wanted—even more than she had given him. Then she and her officials went back to their own country. Solomon’s Wealth - Hiram’s and Solomon’s sailors brought gold, juniper wood, and jewels from the country of Ophir. Solomon used the wood to make steps for the temple and palace, and harps and other stringed instruments for the musicians. Nothing like these had ever been made in Judah.

11.verse: In return, Solomon gave her everything she wanted—even more than she had given him. Then she and her officials went back to their own country. 13.verse: Solomon received about twenty-five tons of gold each year,

14.verse: not counting what the merchants and traders brought him. The kings of Arabia and the leaders of Israel also gave him gold and silver.

15.verse: Solomon made two hundred gold shields that weighed about seven and a half pounds each.

16.verse: He also made three hundred smaller gold shields that weighed almost four pounds, and he put these shields in his palace in Forest Hall.

17.verse: His throne was made of ivory and covered with pure gold.

18.verse: It had a gold footstool attached to it and armrests on each side. There was a statue of a lion on each side of the throne,

19.verse: and there were two lion statues on each of the six steps leading up to the throne. No other throne in the world was like Solomon’s.

20.verse: Solomon’s cups and dishes in Forest Hall were made of pure gold, because silver was almost worthless in those days.

21.verse: Solomon had a lot of seagoing ships. Every three years he sent them out with Hiram’s ships to bring back gold, silver, and ivory, as well as monkeys and peacocks.

22.verse: Solomon was the richest and wisest king in the world.

23.verse: Year after year, other kings came to hear the wisdom God had given him. And they brought gifts of silver and gold, as well as clothes, weapons, spices, horses, and mules.

24.verse: Year after year, other kings came to hear the wisdom God had given him. And they brought gifts of silver and gold, as well as clothes, weapons, spices, horses, and mules.

25.verse: Solomon had four thousand stalls for his horses and chariots, and he owned twelve thousand horses that he kept in Jerusalem and other towns.

26.verse: He ruled all the nations from the Euphrates River in the north to the land of Philistia in the south, as far as the border of Egypt.

27.verse: While Solomon was king, there was silver everywhere in Jerusalem, and cedar was as common as the sycamore trees in the western foothills.

28.verse: Solomon’s horses were brought in from other countries, including Musri.

29.verse: Solomon Dies - Everything else Solomon did while he was king is written in the records of Nathan the prophet, Ahijah the prophet from Shiloh, and Iddo the prophet who wrote about Jeroboam son of Nebat.

30.verse: After Solomon had ruled forty years from Jerusalem,

31.verse: he died and was buried in the city of his father David. His son Rehoboam then became king.

1.verse: Some of the People Rebel against Rehoboam - Rehoboam went to Shechem where everyone was waiting to crown him king.

2.verse: Jeroboam son of Nebat heard what was happening, and he returned from Egypt, where he had gone to hide from Solomon.

3.verse: The people from the northern tribes of Israel sent for him. Then together they went to Rehoboam and said,

4.verse: “Your father Solomon forced us to work very hard. But if you make our work easier, we will serve you and do whatever you ask.”

5.verse: Rehoboam replied, “Come back in three days for my answer.” So the people left.

6.verse: Rehoboam went to some leaders who had been his father’s senior officials, and he asked them, “What should I tell these people?”

7.verse: They answered, “If you want them to serve and obey you, then you should be kind and promise to make their work easier.”

8.verse: But Rehoboam refused their advice and went to the younger men who had grown up with him and were now his officials.

9.verse: He asked, “What do you think I should say to these people who asked me to make their work easier?”

10.verse: His younger advisors said: Here’s what we think you should say to them: “Compared to me, my father was weak.

11.verse: He made you work hard, but I’ll make you work even harder. He punished you with whips, but I’ll use whips with pieces of sharp metal!”

12.verse: Three days later, Jeroboam and the others came back.

13.verse: Rehoboam ignored the advice of the older advisors. He spoke bluntly

14.verse: and told them exactly what his own advisors had suggested. He said: “My father made you work hard, but I’ll make you work even harder. He punished you with whips, but I’ll use whips with pieces of sharp metal!”

15.verse: When the people realized that Rehoboam would not listen to them, they shouted: “We don’t have to be loyal to David’s family. We can do what we want. Come on, people of Israel, let’s go home! Rehoboam can rule his own people.” Adoniram was in charge of the work force, and Rehoboam sent him to talk to the people. But they stoned him to death. Then Rehoboam ran to his chariot and hurried back to Jerusalem. Everyone from Israel’s northern tribes went home, leaving Rehoboam to rule only the people from Judah. And since that day, the people of Israel have been opposed to David’s descendants in Judah. All of this happened just as Ahijah the LORD’s prophet from Shiloh had told Jeroboam.
