1.verse: Shemaiah the Prophet Warns Rehoboam - After Rehoboam returned to Jerusalem, he decided to attack Israel and regain control of the whole country. So he called together one hundred eighty thousand soldiers from the tribes of Judah and Benjamin.

2.verse: Meanwhile, the LORD had told Shemaiah the prophet

3.verse: to tell Rehoboam and everyone from Judah and Benjamin,

4.verse: “The LORD warns you not to go to war against the people from the northern tribes—they are your relatives. Go home! The LORD is the one who made these things happen.” Rehoboam and his army obeyed the LORD’s message and did not attack Jeroboam and his troops.

5.verse: Rehoboam Fortifies Cities in Judah - Rehoboam ruled from Jerusalem, and he had several cities in Judah turned into fortresses so he could use them to defend his country. These cities included

6.verse: Bethlehem, Etam, Tekoa,

7.verse: Beth-Zur, Soco, Adullam,

8.verse: Gath, Mareshah, Ziph,

9.verse: Adoraim, Lachish, Azekah,

10.verse: Zorah, Aijalon, and Hebron. After he had fortified these cities in the territories of Judah and Benjamin,

11.verse: he assigned an army commander to each of them and stocked them with supplies of food, olive oil, and wine,

12.verse: as well as with shields and spears. He used these fortified cities to keep control of Judah and Benjamin.

13.verse: The Priests and the Levites Support Rehoboam - The priests and Levites from the northern tribes of Israel gave their support to King Rehoboam.

14.verse: And since Jeroboam and the kings of Israel that followed him would not allow any Levites to serve as priests, most Levites left their towns and pasturelands in Israel and moved to Jerusalem and other towns in Judah.

15.verse: Jeroboam chose his own priests to serve at the local shrines in Israel and at the places of worship where he had set up statues of goat-demons and of calves.

16.verse: But some of the people from Israel wanted to worship the LORD God, just as their ancestors had done. So they followed the priests and Levites to Jerusalem, where they could offer sacrifices to the LORD.

17.verse: For the next three years, they lived in Judah and were loyal to Rehoboam and his kingdom, just as they had been loyal to David and Solomon.

18.verse: Rehoboam’s Family - Rehoboam married Mahalath, whose father was Jerimoth son of David, and whose mother was Abihail the daughter of Eliab and granddaughter of Jesse.

19.verse: Rehoboam and Mahalath had three sons: Jeush, Shemariah, and Zaham.

20.verse: Then Rehoboam married Maacah the daughter of Absalom. Their sons were Abijah, Attai, Ziza, and Shelomith.

21.verse: Rehoboam had eighteen wives, but he also married sixty other women, and he was the father of twenty-eight sons and sixty daughters. Rehoboam loved his wife Maacah the most,

22.verse: so he chose their oldest son Abijah to be the next king.

23.verse: Rehoboam was wise enough to put one of his sons in charge of each fortified city in his kingdom. He gave them all the supplies they needed and found wives for every one of them.

1.verse: King Shishak of Egypt Invades Judah - Soon after Rehoboam had control of his kingdom, he and everyone in Judah stopped obeying the LORD.

2.verse: So in the fifth year of Rehoboam’s rule, the LORD punished them for their unfaithfulness and allowed King Shishak of Egypt to invade Judah.

3.verse: Shishak attacked with his army of one thousand two hundred chariots and sixty thousand cavalry troops, as well as Egyptian soldiers from Libya, Sukkoth, and Ethiopia.

4.verse: He captured every one of the fortified cities in Judah and then marched to Jerusalem.

5.verse: Rehoboam and the leaders of Judah had gone to Jerusalem to escape Shishak’s invasion. And while they were there, Shemaiah the prophet told them, “The LORD says that because you have disobeyed him, he has now abandoned you. The LORD will not help you against Shishak!”

6.verse: Rehoboam and the leaders were sorry for what they had done and admitted, “The LORD is right. We have deserted him.”

7.verse: When the LORD heard this, he told Shemaiah: The people of Judah are truly sorry for their sins, and so I won’t let Shishak completely destroy them. But because I am still angry,

8.verse: he will conquer and rule them. Then my people will know what it’s like to serve a foreign king instead of serving me.

9.verse: Shishak attacked Jerusalem and took all the valuable things from the temple and from the palace, including Solomon’s gold shields.

10.verse: Rehoboam had bronze shields made to replace the gold ones, and he ordered the guards at the city gates to keep them safe.

11.verse: Whenever Rehoboam went to the LORD’s temple, the guards carried the shields. But they always took them back to the guardroom as soon as he had finished worshiping.

12.verse: Rehoboam turned back to the LORD, and so the LORD did not let Judah be completely destroyed, and Judah was prosperous again.

13.verse: Rehoboam’s Rule in Judah - Rehoboam was forty-one years old when he became king, and he ruled seventeen years from Jerusalem, the city where the LORD had chosen to be worshiped. His mother Naamah was from Ammon. Rehoboam was a powerful king,

14.verse: but he still did wrong and refused to obey the LORD.

15.verse: Everything else Rehoboam did while he was king, including a history of his family, is written in the records of the two prophets, Shemaiah and Iddo. During Rehoboam’s rule, he and King Jeroboam of Israel were constantly at war.

16.verse: When Rehoboam died, he was buried beside his ancestors in Jerusalem, and his son Abijah became king.

1.verse: King Abijah of Judah - Abijah became king of Judah in Jeroboam’s eighteenth year as king of Israel,

2.verse: and he ruled from Jerusalem for three years. His mother was Micaiah the daughter of Uriel from Gibeah. Some time later, Abijah and King Jeroboam of Israel went to war against each other.

3.verse: Abijah’s army had four hundred thousand troops, and Jeroboam met him in battle with eight hundred thousand troops.

4.verse: Abijah went to the top of Mount Zemaraim in the hills of Ephraim and shouted: Listen, Jeroboam and all you Israelites!

5.verse: The LORD God of Israel has made a solemn promise that every king of Israel will be from David’s family.

6.verse: But Jeroboam, you were King Solomon’s official, and you rebelled.

7.verse: Then right after Rehoboam became king, you and your bunch of worthless followers challenged Rehoboam, who was too young to know how to stop you.

8.verse: Now you and your powerful army think you can stand up to the kingdom that the LORD has given to David’s descendants. The only gods you have are those gold statues of calves that Jeroboam made for you.

9.verse: You don’t even have descendants of Aaron on your side, because you forced out the LORD’s priests and Levites. In their place, you appoint ordinary people to be priests, just as the foreign nations do. In fact, anyone who brings a bull and seven rams to the altar can become a priest of your so-called gods.

10.verse: But we have not turned our backs on the LORD God! Aaron’s own descendants serve as our priests, and the Levites are their assistants.

11.verse: Two times every day they offer sacrifices and burn incense to the LORD. They set out the sacred loaves of bread on a table that has been purified, and they light the lamps in the gold lampstand every day at sunset. We follow the commands of the LORD our God—you have rejected him!

12.verse: That’s why God is on our side and will lead us into battle when the priests sound the signal on the trumpets. It’s no use, Israelites. You might as well give up. There’s no way you can defeat the LORD, the God your ancestors worshiped.

13.verse: But while Abijah was talking, Jeroboam had sent some of his troops to attack Judah’s army from behind, while the rest attacked from the front.

14.verse: Judah’s army realized they were trapped, and so they prayed to the LORD. The priests blew the signal on the trumpet,

15.verse: and the troops let out a battle cry. Then with Abijah leading them into battle, God defeated Jeroboam and Israel’s army.

16.verse: The Israelites ran away, and God helped Judah’s soldiers slaughter

17.verse: five hundred thousand enemy troops.

18.verse: Judah’s army won because they had trusted the LORD God of their ancestors.

19.verse: Abijah kept up his attack on Jeroboam’s army and captured the Israelite towns of Bethel, Jeshanah, and Ephron, as well as the villages around them.

20.verse: Jeroboam never regained his power during the rest of Abijah’s rule. The LORD punished Jeroboam, and he died, but Abijah became more powerful.

21.verse: Abijah had a total of fourteen wives, twenty-two sons, and sixteen daughters.

22.verse: Everything Abijah said and did while he was king is written in the records of Iddo the prophet.

1.verse: King Asa of Judah - Abijah died and was buried in Jerusalem. Then his son Asa became king, and Judah had ten years of peace.

2.verse: Asa obeyed the LORD his God and did right.

3.verse: He destroyed the local shrines and the altars to foreign gods. He smashed the stone images of gods and cut down the sacred poles used in worshiping the goddess Asherah.

4.verse: Then he told everyone in Judah to worship the LORD God, just as their ancestors had done, and to obey his laws and teachings.

5.verse: He destroyed every local shrine and incense altar in Judah.

6.verse: The LORD blessed Judah with peace while Asa was king, and so during that time, Asa fortified many of the towns.

7.verse: He said to the people, “Let’s build walls and defense towers for these towns, and put in gates that can be locked with bars. This land still belongs to us, because we have obeyed the LORD our God. He has given us peace from all our enemies.” The people did everything Asa had suggested.

8.verse: Asa had a large army of brave soldiers: Three hundred thousand of them were from the tribe of Judah and were armed with shields and spears; two hundred eighty thousand were from Benjamin and were armed with bows and arrows.

9.verse: Judah Defeats Ethiopia’s Army - Zerah from Ethiopia led an army of a million soldiers and three hundred chariots to the town of Mareshah in Judah.

10.verse: Asa met him there, and the two armies prepared for battle in Zephathah Valley.

11.verse: Asa prayed: LORD God, only you can help a powerless army defeat a stronger one. So we depend on you to help us. We will fight against this powerful army to honor your name, and we know that you won’t be defeated. You are the LORD our God.

12.verse: The LORD helped Asa and his army defeat the Ethiopians. The enemy soldiers ran away,

13.verse: but Asa and his troops chased them as far as Gerar. It was a total defeat—the Ethiopians could not even fight back! The soldiers from Judah took everything that had belonged to the Ethiopians.

14.verse: The people who lived in the villages around Gerar learned what had happened and were afraid of the LORD. So Judah’s army easily defeated them and carried off everything of value that they wanted from these towns.

15.verse: They also attacked the camps where the shepherds lived and took a lot of sheep, goats, and camels. Then they went back to Jerusalem.

1.verse: Asa Destroys the Idols in Judah - Some time later, God spoke to Azariah son of Oded.

2.verse: At once, Azariah went to Asa and said: Listen to me, King Asa and you people of Judah and Benjamin. The LORD will be with you and help you, as long as you obey and worship him. But if you disobey him, he will desert you.

3.verse: For a long time, the people of Israel did not worship the true God or listen to priests who could teach them about God. They refused to obey God’s Law.

4.verse: But whenever trouble came, Israel turned back to the LORD their God and worshiped him.

5.verse: There was so much confusion in those days that it wasn’t safe to go anywhere in Israel.

6.verse: Nations were destroying each other, and cities were wiping out other cities, because God was causing trouble and unrest everywhere.

7.verse: So you must be brave. Don’t give up! God will honor you for obeying him.

8.verse: As soon as Asa heard what Azariah the prophet said, he gave orders for all the idols in Judah and Benjamin to be destroyed, including those in the towns he had captured in the territory of Ephraim. He also repaired the LORD’s altar that was in front of the temple porch.

9.verse: Asa called together the people from Judah and Benjamin, as well as the people from the territories of Ephraim, West Manasseh, and Simeon who were living in Judah. Many of these people were now loyal to Asa, because they had seen that the LORD was with him.

10.verse: In the third month of the fifteenth year of Asa’s rule, they all met in Jerusalem.

11.verse: That same day, they took seven hundred bulls and seven thousand sheep and goats from what they had brought back from Gerar and sacrificed them as offerings to the LORD.

12.verse: They made a solemn promise to faithfully worship the LORD God their ancestors had worshiped,

13.verse: and to put to death anyone who refused to obey him.

14.verse: The crowd solemnly agreed to keep their promise to the LORD, then they celebrated by shouting and blowing trumpets and horns.

15.verse: Everyone was happy because they had made this solemn promise, and in return, the LORD blessed them with peace from all their enemies.

16.verse: Asa’s grandmother Maacah had made a disgusting idol of the goddess Asherah, so he cut it down, crushed it, and burned it in Kidron Valley. Then he removed Maacah from her position as queen mother.

17.verse: As long as Asa lived, he was faithful to the LORD, even though he did not destroy the local shrines in Israel.

18.verse: He placed in the temple all the silver and gold objects that he and his father had dedicated to God.

19.verse: There was peace in Judah until the thirty-fifth year of Asa’s rule.

1.verse: King Baasha of Israel Invades Judah - In the thirty-sixth year of Asa’s rule, King Baasha of Israel invaded Judah and captured the town of Ramah. He started making the town stronger, and he put troops there to stop people from going in and out of Judah.

2.verse: When Asa heard about this, he took the silver and gold from his palace and from the LORD’s temple. Then he sent it to Damascus with this message for King Benhadad of Syria:

3.verse: “I think we should sign a peace treaty, just as our fathers did. This silver and gold is a present for you. Would you please break your treaty with King Baasha of Israel and force him to leave my country?”

4.verse: Benhadad did what Asa asked and sent the Syrian army into Israel. They captured the towns of Ijon, Dan, Abel-Maim, and all the towns in Naphtali where supplies were kept.

5.verse: When Baasha heard about it, he stopped his work on the town of Ramah.

6.verse: Asa ordered everyone in Judah to carry away the stones and wood Baasha had used to fortify Ramah. Then he fortified the towns of Geba and Mizpah with these same stones and wood.

7.verse: Hanani the Prophet Condemns Asa - Soon after that happened, Hanani the prophet went to Asa and said: You depended on the king of Syria instead of depending on the LORD your God. And so, you will never defeat the Syrian army.

8.verse: Remember how powerful the Ethiopian and Libyan army was, with all their chariots and cavalry troops! You trusted the LORD to help you then, and you defeated them.

9.verse: The LORD is constantly watching everyone, and he gives strength to those who faithfully obey him. But you have done a foolish thing, and your kingdom will never be at peace again.

10.verse: When Asa heard this, he was so angry that he put Hanani in prison. Asa was also cruel to some of his people.

11.verse: Asa Dies - Everything Asa did while he was king is written in The History of the Kings of Judah and Israel.

12.verse: In the thirty-ninth year of his rule, he got a very bad foot disease, but he relied on doctors and refused to ask the LORD for help.

13.verse: He died two years later.

14.verse: Earlier, Asa had his own tomb cut out of a rock hill in Jerusalem. So he was buried there, and the tomb was filled with spices and sweet-smelling oils. Then the people built a bonfire in his honor.

1.verse: King Jehoshaphat of Judah - Jehoshaphat son of Asa became king and strengthened his defenses against Israel.

2.verse: He assigned troops to the fortified cities in Judah, as well as to other towns in Judah and to those towns in Ephraim that his father Asa had captured.

3.verse: When Jehoshaphat’s father had first become king of Judah, he was faithful to the LORD and refused to worship the god Baal as the kings of Israel did. Jehoshaphat followed his father’s example and obeyed and worshiped the LORD. And so the LORD blessed Jehoshaphat

4.verse: When Jehoshaphat’s father had first become king of Judah, he was faithful to the LORD and refused to worship the god Baal as the kings of Israel did. Jehoshaphat followed his father’s example and obeyed and worshiped the LORD. And so the LORD blessed Jehoshaphat

5.verse: and helped him keep firm control of his kingdom. The people of Judah brought gifts to Jehoshaphat, but even after he became very rich and respected,

6.verse: he remained completely faithful to the LORD. He destroyed all the local shrines in Judah, including the places where the goddess Asherah was worshiped.

7.verse: In the third year of Jehoshaphat’s rule, he chose five officials and gave them orders to teach the LORD’s Law in every city and town in Judah. They were Benhail, Obadiah, Zechariah, Nethanel, and Micaiah.

8.verse: Their assistants were the following nine Levites: Shemaiah, Nethaniah, Zebadiah, Asahel, Shemiramoth, Jehonathan, Adonijah, Tobijah, and Tob-Adonijah. Two priests, Elishama and Jehoram, also went along.

9.verse: They carried with them a copy of the LORD’s Law wherever they went and taught the people from it.

10.verse: The nations around Judah were afraid of the LORD’s power, so none of them attacked Jehoshaphat.

11.verse: Philistines brought him silver and other gifts to keep peace. Some of the Arab people brought him seventy-seven hundred rams and the same number of goats.

12.verse: As Jehoshaphat became more powerful, he built fortresses and cities

13.verse: where he stored supplies. He also kept in Jerusalem some experienced soldiers

14.verse: from the Judah and Benjamin tribes. These soldiers were grouped according to their clans. Adnah was the commander of the troops from Judah, and he had three hundred thousand soldiers under his command.

15.verse: Jehohanan was second in command, with two hundred eighty thousand soldiers under him.

16.verse: Amasiah son of Zichri, who had volunteered to serve the LORD, was third in command, with two hundred thousand soldiers under him.

17.verse: Eliada was a brave warrior who commanded the troops from Benjamin. He had two hundred thousand soldiers under his command, all of them armed with bows and shields.

18.verse: Jehozabad was second in command, with one hundred eighty thousand soldiers under him.

19.verse: These were the troops who protected the king in Jerusalem, not counting those he had assigned to the fortified cities throughout the country.

1.verse: Micaiah Warns King Ahab of Israel - Jehoshaphat was now very rich and famous. He signed a treaty with King Ahab of Israel by arranging the marriage of his son and Ahab’s daughter.

2.verse: One day, Jehoshaphat went to visit Ahab in his capital city of Samaria. Ahab slaughtered sheep and cattle and prepared a big feast to honor Jehoshaphat and the officials with him. Ahab talked about attacking the city of Ramoth in Gilead,

3.verse: and finally asked, “Jehoshaphat, would you go with me to attack Ramoth?” “Yes,” Jehoshaphat answered. “My army is at your command.

4.verse: But first let’s ask the LORD what to do.”

5.verse: Ahab sent for four hundred prophets and asked, “Should I attack the city of Ramoth?” “Yes!” the prophets answered. “God will help you capture the city.”

6.verse: But Jehoshaphat said, “Just to make sure, is there another of the LORD’s prophets we can ask?”

7.verse: “We could ask Micaiah son of Imlah,” Ahab said. “But I hate Micaiah. He always has bad news for me.” “Don’t say that!” Jehoshaphat replied.

8.verse: Then Ahab sent someone to bring Micaiah as soon as possible.

9.verse: All this time, Ahab and Jehoshaphat were dressed in their royal robes and were seated on their thrones at the threshing place near the gate of Samaria, listening to the prophets tell them what the LORD had said.

10.verse: Zedekiah son of Chenaanah was one of the prophets. He had made some horns out of iron and shouted, “Ahab, the LORD says you will attack the Syrians like a bull with iron horns and wipe them out!”

11.verse: All the prophets agreed that Ahab should attack the Syrians at Ramoth and promised that the LORD would help him defeat them.

12.verse: Meanwhile, the messenger who went to get Micaiah whispered, “Micaiah, all the prophets have good news for Ahab. Now go and say the same thing.”

13.verse: “I’ll say whatever the living LORD my God tells me to say,” Micaiah replied.

14.verse: Then Micaiah went up to Ahab, who asked, “Micaiah, should we attack Ramoth?” “Yes!” Micaiah answered. “The LORD will help you capture the city.”

15.verse: Ahab shouted, “Micaiah, I’ve told you over and over to tell me the truth! What does the LORD really say?”

16.verse: Micaiah answered, “In a vision I saw Israelite soldiers wandering around, lost in the hills like sheep without a shepherd. The LORD said, ‘These troops have no leader. They should go home and not fight.’”

17.verse: Ahab turned to Jehoshaphat and said, “I told you he would bring me bad news!”

18.verse: Micaiah replied: I then saw the LORD seated on his throne with every creature in heaven gathered around him.

19.verse: The LORD asked, “Who can trick Ahab and make him go to Ramoth where he will be killed?” They talked about it for a while,

20.verse: then finally a spirit came forward and said to the LORD, “I can trick Ahab.” “How?” the LORD asked.

21.verse: “I’ll make Ahab’s prophets lie to him.” “Good!” the LORD replied. “Now go and do it. You will be successful.”

22.verse: Ahab, this is exactly what has happened. The LORD made all your prophets lie to you, and he knows you will soon be destroyed.

23.verse: Zedekiah walked over and slapped Micaiah on the face. Then he asked, “Do you really think the LORD would speak to you and not to me?”

24.verse: Micaiah answered, “You’ll find out on the day you have to hide in the back room of some house.”

25.verse: Ahab shouted, “Arrest Micaiah! Take him to Prince Joash and Governor Amon of Samaria.

26.verse: Tell them to put him in prison and to give him nothing but bread and water until I come back safely.”

27.verse: Micaiah said, “If you do come back, I was wrong about what the LORD wanted me to say.” Then he told the crowd, “Don’t forget what I said!”

28.verse: Ahab Dies at Ramoth - Ahab and Jehoshaphat led their armies to Ramoth in Gilead.

29.verse: Before they went into battle, Ahab said, “Jehoshaphat, I’ll disguise myself, but you wear your royal robe.” Ahab disguised himself and went into battle.

30.verse: The king of Syria had ordered his chariot commanders to attack only Ahab.

31.verse: So when they saw Jehoshaphat in his robe, they thought he was Ahab and started to attack him. But Jehoshaphat prayed, and the LORD made the Syrian soldiers stop.

32.verse: And when they realized he wasn’t Ahab, they left him alone.

33.verse: However, during the fighting a soldier shot an arrow without even aiming, and it hit Ahab between two pieces of his armor. He shouted to his chariot driver, “I’ve been hit! Get me out of here!”

34.verse: The fighting lasted all day, with Ahab propped up in his chariot so he could see the Syrian troops. He stayed there until evening, and by sundown he was dead.

1.verse: Jehoshaphat returned safely to his palace in Jerusalem.

2.verse: But the prophet Jehu son of Hanani met him and said: By helping that wicked Ahab, you have made friends with someone who hates the LORD. Now the LORD God is angry at you!

3.verse: But not everything about you is bad. You destroyed the sacred poles used in worshiping the goddess Asherah—that shows you have tried to obey the LORD.

4.verse: Jehoshaphat Appoints Judges To Settle Cases - Jehoshaphat lived in Jerusalem, but he often traveled through his kingdom, from Beersheba in the south to the edge of the hill country of Ephraim in the north. He talked with the people and convinced them to turn back to the LORD God and worship him, just as their ancestors had done.

5.verse: He assigned judges to each of the fortified cities in Judah

6.verse: and told them: Be careful when you make your decisions in court, because these are the LORD’s people, and he will know what you decide.

7.verse: So do your work in honor of him and know that he won’t allow you to be unfair to anyone or to take bribes.

8.verse: Jehoshaphat also chose some Levites, some priests, and some of the family leaders, and he appointed them to serve as judges in Jerusalem.

9.verse: He told them: Faithfully serve the LORD!

10.verse: The people of Judah will bring you legal cases that involve every type of crime, including murder. You must settle these cases and warn the people to stop sinning against the LORD, so that he won’t get angry and punish Judah. Remember, if you follow these instructions, you won’t be held responsible for anything that happens.

11.verse: Amariah the high priest will have the final say in any religious case. And Zebadiah, the leader of the Judah tribe, will have the final say in all other cases. The rest of the Levites will serve as your assistants. Be brave, and I pray that the LORD will help you do right.

1.verse: Moab and Ammon Are Defeated - Some time later, the armies of Moab and Ammon, together with the Meunites, went to war against Jehoshaphat.

2.verse: Messengers told Jehoshaphat, “A large army from Edom east of the Dead Sea has invaded our country. They have already reached En-Gedi.”

3.verse: Jehoshaphat was afraid, so he asked the LORD what to do. He then told the people of Judah to go without eating to show their sorrow.

4.verse: They immediately left for Jerusalem to ask for the LORD’s help.

5.verse: After everyone from Judah and Jerusalem had come together at the LORD’s temple, Jehoshaphat stood in front of the new courtyard

6.verse: and prayed: You, LORD, are the God our ancestors worshiped, and from heaven you rule every nation in the world. You are so powerful that no one can defeat you.

7.verse: Our God, you forced out the nations who lived in this land before your people Israel came here, and you gave it to the descendants of your friend Abraham forever.

8.verse: Our ancestors lived in this land and built a temple to honor you.

9.verse: They believed that whenever this land is struck by war or disease or famine, your people can pray to you at the temple, and you will hear their prayer and save them.

10.verse: You can see that the armies of Ammon, Moab, and Edom are attacking us! Those are the nations you would not let our ancestors invade on their way from Egypt, so these nations were not destroyed.

11.verse: Now they are coming to take back the land you gave us.

12.verse: Aren’t you going to punish them? We won’t stand a chance when this army attacks. We don’t know what to do—we are begging for your help.

13.verse: While every man, woman, and child of Judah was standing there at the temple,

14.verse: the LORD’s Spirit suddenly spoke to Jahaziel, a Levite from the Asaph clan.

15.verse: Then Jahaziel said: Your Majesty and everyone from Judah and Jerusalem, the LORD says that you don’t need to be afraid or let this powerful army discourage you. God will fight on your side!

16.verse: So here’s what you must do. Tomorrow the enemy armies will march through the desert around the town of Jeruel. March down and meet them at the town of Ziz as they come up the valley.

17.verse: You won’t even have to fight. Just take your positions and watch the LORD rescue you from your enemy. Don’t be afraid. Just do as you’re told. And as you march out tomorrow, the LORD will be there with you.

18.verse: Jehoshaphat bowed low to the ground and everyone worshiped the LORD.

19.verse: Then some Levites from the Kohath and Korah clans stood up and shouted praises to the LORD God of Israel.

20.verse: Early the next morning, as everyone got ready to leave for the desert near Tekoa, Jehoshaphat stood up and said, “Listen my friends, if we trust the LORD God and believe what these prophets have told us, the LORD will help us, and we will be successful.”

21.verse: Then he explained his plan and appointed men to march in front of the army and praise the LORD for his holy power by singing: “Praise the LORD! His love never ends.”

22.verse: As soon as they began singing, the LORD confused the enemy camp,

23.verse: so that the Ammonite and Moabite troops attacked and completely destroyed those from Edom. Then they turned against each other and fought until the entire camp was wiped out!

24.verse: When Judah’s army reached the tower that overlooked the desert, they saw that every soldier in the enemy’s army was lying dead on the ground.

25.verse: So Jehoshaphat and his troops went into the camp to carry away everything of value. They found a large herd of livestock, a lot of equipment, clothes, and other valuable things. It took them three days to carry it all away, and there was still some left over.

26.verse: Then on the fourth day, everyone came together in Beracah Valley and sang praises to the LORD. That’s why that place was called Praise Valley.

27.verse: Jehoshaphat led the crowd back to Jerusalem. And as they marched, they played harps and blew trumpets. They were very happy because the LORD had given them victory over their enemies, so when they reached the city, they went straight to the temple.

28.verse: Jehoshaphat led the crowd back to Jerusalem. And as they marched, they played harps and blew trumpets. They were very happy because the LORD had given them victory over their enemies, so when they reached the city, they went straight to the temple.

29.verse: When the other nations heard how the LORD had fought against Judah’s enemies, they were too afraid

30.verse: to invade Judah. The LORD let Jehoshaphat’s kingdom be at peace.

31.verse: Jehoshaphat Dies - Jehoshaphat was thirty-five years old when he became king of Judah, and he ruled from Jerusalem for twenty-five years. His mother was Azubah daughter of Shilhi.

32.verse: Jehoshaphat obeyed the LORD, just as his father Asa had done,

33.verse: but he did not destroy the local shrines. So the people still worshiped foreign gods, instead of faithfully serving the God their ancestors had worshiped.

34.verse: Everything else Jehoshaphat did while he was king is written in the records of Jehu son of Hanani that are included in The History of the Kings of Israel.

35.verse: While Jehoshaphat was king, he signed a peace treaty with Ahaziah the wicked king of Israel.

36.verse: They agreed to build several seagoing ships at Ezion-Geber.

37.verse: But the prophet Eliezer warned Jehoshaphat, “The LORD will destroy these ships because you have supported Ahaziah.” The ships were wrecked and never sailed.

1.verse: Jehoshaphat died and was buried beside his ancestors in Jerusalem, and his son Jehoram became king.

2.verse: King Jehoram of Judah - King Jehoshaphat had seven sons: Jehoram, Azariah, Jehiel, Zechariah, Azariah, Michael, and Shephatiah.

3.verse: Jehoshaphat gave each of them silver and gold, as well as other valuable gifts. He also put them in charge of the fortified cities in Judah, but he had chosen his oldest son Jehoram to succeed him as king.

4.verse: After Jehoram had taken control of Judah, he had his brothers killed, as well as some of the nation’s leaders.

5.verse: He was thirty-two years old when he became king, and he ruled eight years from Jerusalem.

6.verse: Jehoram married Ahab’s daughter and followed the sinful example of Ahab’s family and the other kings of Israel. He disobeyed the LORD by doing wrong,

7.verse: but because the LORD had made a solemn promise to King David that someone from his family would always rule in Judah, he refused to wipe out David’s descendants.

8.verse: While Jehoram was king, the people of Edom rebelled and chose their own king.

9.verse: Jehoram, his officers, and his cavalry marched to Edom, where the Edomite army surrounded them. He escaped during the night,

10.verse: but Judah was never able to regain control of Edom. Even the town of Libnah rebelled at that time. Those things happened because Jehoram had turned away from the LORD, the God his ancestors had worshiped.

11.verse: Jehoram even built local shrines in the hills of Judah and let the people sin against the LORD by worshiping foreign gods.

12.verse: One day, Jehoram received a letter from Elijah the prophet that said: I have a message for you from the LORD God your ancestor David worshiped. He knows that you have not followed the example of Jehoshaphat your father or Asa your grandfather.

13.verse: Instead you have acted like those sinful kings of Israel and have encouraged the people of Judah to stop worshiping the LORD, just as Ahab and his descendants did. You even murdered your own brothers, who were better men than you.

14.verse: Because you have done these terrible things, the LORD will severely punish the people in your kingdom, including your own family, and he will destroy everything you own.

15.verse: You will be struck with a painful stomach disease and suffer until you die.

16.verse: The LORD later caused the Philistines and the Arabs who lived near the Ethiopians to become angry at Jehoram.

17.verse: They invaded Judah and stole the royal property from the palace, and they led Jehoram’s wives and sons away as prisoners. The only one left behind was Ahaziah, his youngest son.

18.verse: After this happened, the LORD struck Jehoram with an incurable stomach disease.

19.verse: About two years later, Jehoram died in terrible pain. No bonfire was built to honor him, even though the people had done this for his ancestors.

20.verse: Jehoram was thirty-two years old when he became king, and he ruled eight years from Jerusalem. He died, and no one even felt sad. He was buried in Jerusalem, but not in the royal tombs.

1.verse: King Ahaziah of Judah - Earlier, when the Arabs led a raid against Judah, they killed all of Jehoram’s sons, except Ahaziah, the youngest one. So the people of Jerusalem crowned him their king.

2.verse: He was twenty-two years old at the time, and he ruled only one year from Jerusalem. Ahaziah’s mother was Athaliah, a granddaughter of King Omri of Israel,

3.verse: and she encouraged her son to sin against the LORD. He followed the evil example of King Ahab and his descendants.

4.verse: In fact, after his father’s death, Ahaziah sinned against the LORD by appointing some of Ahab’s relatives to be his advisors. Their advice led to his downfall.

5.verse: He listened to them and went with King Joram of Israel to attack King Hazael and the Syrian troops at Ramoth in Gilead. Joram was wounded in that battle,

6.verse: and he went to the town of Jezreel to recover. And Ahaziah later went there to visit him.

7.verse: It was during that visit that God had Ahaziah put to death. When Ahaziah arrived at Jezreel, he and Joram went to meet with Jehu grandson of Nimshi. The LORD had already told Jehu to kill every male in Ahab’s family,

8.verse: and while Jehu was doing that, he saw some of Judah’s leaders and Ahaziah’s nephews who had come with Ahaziah. Jehu killed them on the spot,

9.verse: then gave orders to find Ahaziah. Jehu’s officers found him hiding in Samaria. They brought Ahaziah to Jehu, who immediately put him to death. They buried Ahaziah only because they respected Jehoshaphat his grandfather, who had done his best to obey the LORD. There was no one from Ahaziah’s family left to become king of Judah.

10.verse: Queen Athaliah of Judah - As soon as Athaliah heard that her son King Ahaziah was dead, she decided to kill any relative who could possibly become king. She would have done just that,

11.verse: but Jehosheba rescued Joash son of Ahaziah just as the others were about to be murdered. Jehosheba, who was Jehoram’s daughter and Ahaziah’s half sister, was married to Jehoiada the priest. So she was able to hide her nephew Joash and his personal servant in a bedroom in the LORD’s temple where he was safe from Athaliah.

12.verse: Joash hid in the temple with them for six years while Athaliah ruled as queen of Judah.

1.verse: Jehoiada Makes Joash King of Judah - After Ahaziah’s son Joash had hidden in the temple for six years, Jehoiada the priest knew that something had to be done. So he made sure he had the support of several army officers. They were Azariah son of Jeroham, Ishmael son of Jehohanan, Azariah son of Obed, Maaseiah son of Adaiah, and Elishaphat son of Zichri.

2.verse: These five men went to the towns in Judah and called together the Levites and the clan leaders. They all came to Jerusalem

3.verse: and gathered at the temple, where they agreed to help Joash. Jehoiada said to them: Joash will be our next king, because long ago the LORD promised that one of David’s descendants would always be king.

4.verse: Here is what we will do. Three groups of priests and Levites will be on guard duty on the Sabbath—one group will guard the gates of the temple,

5.verse: one will guard the palace, and the other will guard Foundation Gate. The rest of you will stand guard in the temple courtyards.

6.verse: Only the priests and Levites who are on duty will be able to enter the temple, because they will be the only ones who have gone through the ceremony to make themselves clean and acceptable. The others must stay outside in the courtyards, just as the LORD has commanded.

7.verse: You Levites must protect King Joash. Don’t let him out of your sight! And keep your swords ready to kill anyone who comes into the temple.

8.verse: The Levites and the people of Judah followed Jehoiada’s orders. The guards going off duty were not allowed to go home, and so each commander had all his guards available—those going off duty as well as those coming on duty.

9.verse: Jehoiada went into the temple and brought out the swords and shields that had belonged to King David, and he gave them to the commanders.

10.verse: They gave the weapons to the guards, and Jehoiada then made sure that the guards took their positions around the temple and the altar to protect the king on every side.

11.verse: Jehoiada and his sons brought Joash outside, where they placed the crown on his head and gave him a copy of the instructions for ruling the nation. Olive oil was poured on his head to show that he was now king, and the crowd cheered and shouted, “Long live the king!”

12.verse: As soon as Queen Athaliah heard the crowd cheering for Joash, she went to the temple.

13.verse: There she saw Joash standing by one of the columns near the entrance, which was the usual place for the king. The commanders and the trumpet players were standing next to him, and the musicians were playing instruments and leading the people as they celebrated and blew trumpets. Athaliah tore her clothes in anger and shouted, “You betrayed me, you traitors!”

14.verse: Right away, Jehoiada said to the army commanders, “Don’t kill her near the LORD’s temple. Take her out in front of the troops, and be sure to kill all of her followers!”

15.verse: She tried to escape, but the commanders caught and killed her near the gate where horses are led into the palace.

16.verse: Jehoiada asked King Joash and the people to join with him in being faithful to the LORD. They agreed,

17.verse: then rushed to the temple of the god Baal and tore it down. They smashed the altars and the idols and killed Mattan the priest of Baal in front of the altars.

18.verse: Jehoiada assigned the priests and Levites their duties at the temple, just as David had done. They were in charge of offering sacrifices to the LORD according to the Law of Moses, and they were responsible for leading the celebrations with singing.

19.verse: Jehoiada ordered the guards at the temple gates to keep out anyone who was unclean.

20.verse: Finally, Jehoiada called together the army commanders, the most important citizens of Judah, and the government officials. The crowd of people followed them as they led Joash from the temple, through the Upper Gate, and into the palace, where he took his place as king of Judah.

21.verse: Everyone celebrated because Athaliah had been killed and Jerusalem was peaceful again.

1.verse: King Joash of Judah - Joash was only seven years old when he became king of Judah, and he ruled forty years from Jerusalem. His mother Zibiah was from the town of Beersheba.

2.verse: While Jehoiada the priest was alive, Joash obeyed the LORD by doing right.

3.verse: Jehoiada even chose two women for Joash to marry so he could have a family.

4.verse: Some time later, Joash decided it was time to repair the temple.

5.verse: He called together the priests and Levites and said, “Go everywhere in Judah and collect the annual tax from the people. I want this done right away—we need that money to repair the temple.” But the Levites were in no hurry to follow the king’s orders.

6.verse: So he sent for Jehoiada the high priest and asked, “Why didn’t you send the Levites to collect the taxes? The LORD’s servant Moses and the people agreed long ago that this tax would be collected and used to pay for the upkeep of the sacred tent.

7.verse: And now we need it to repair the temple because the sons of that evil woman Athaliah came in and wrecked it. They even used some of the sacred objects to worship the god Baal.”

8.verse: Joash gave orders for a wooden box to be made and had it placed outside, near the gate of the temple.

9.verse: He then sent letters everywhere in Judah and Jerusalem, asking everyone to bring their taxes to the temple, just as Moses had required their ancestors to do.

10.verse: The people and their leaders agreed, and they brought their money to Jerusalem and placed it in the box.

11.verse: Each day, after the Levites took the box into the temple, the king’s secretary and the high priest’s assistant would dump out the money and count it. Then the empty box would be taken back outside. This happened day after day, and soon a large amount of money was collected.

12.verse: Joash and Jehoiada turned the money over to the men who were supervising the repairs to the temple. They used the money to hire stonecutters, carpenters, and experts in working with iron and bronze.

13.verse: These workers went right to work repairing the temple, and when they were finished, it looked as good as new.

14.verse: They did not use all the tax money for the repairs, so the rest of it was handed over to Joash and Jehoiada, who then used it to make dishes and other gold and silver objects for the temple. Sacrifices to please the LORD were offered regularly in the temple for as long as Jehoiada lived.

15.verse: He died at the ripe old age of one hundred thirty years,

16.verse: and he was buried in the royal tombs in Jerusalem, because he had done so much good for the people of Israel, for God, and for the temple.

17.verse: Joash Turns Away from the LORD - After the death of Jehoiada the priest, the leaders of Judah went to Joash and talked him into doing what they wanted.

18.verse: Right away, the people of Judah stopped worshiping in the temple of the LORD God, and they started worshiping idols and the symbols of the goddess Asherah. These sinful things made the LORD God angry at the people of Judah and Jerusalem,

19.verse: but he still sent prophets who warned them to turn back to him. The people refused to listen.

20.verse: God’s Spirit spoke to Zechariah son of Jehoiada the priest, and Zechariah told everyone that God was saying: “Why are you disobeying me and my laws? This will only bring punishment! You have deserted me, so now I will desert you.”

21.verse: King Joash forgot that Zechariah’s father had always been a loyal friend. So when the people of Judah plotted to kill Zechariah, Joash joined them and gave orders for them to stone him to death in the courtyard of the temple. As Zechariah was dying, he said, “I pray that the LORD will see this and punish all of you.”

22.verse: King Joash forgot that Zechariah’s father had always been a loyal friend. So when the people of Judah plotted to kill Zechariah, Joash joined them and gave orders for them to stone him to death in the courtyard of the temple. As Zechariah was dying, he said, “I pray that the LORD will see this and punish all of you.”

23.verse: Joash Is Killed - In the spring of the following year, the Syrian army invaded Judah and Jerusalem, killing all of the nation’s leaders. They collected everything of value that belonged to the people and took it back to their king in Damascus.

24.verse: The Syrian army was very small, but the LORD let them defeat Judah’s large army, because he was punishing Joash and the people of Judah for turning away from him.

25.verse: Joash was severely wounded during the battle, and as soon as the Syrians left Judah, two of his officials, Zabad and Jehozabad, decided to revenge the death of Zechariah. They plotted and killed Joash while he was in bed, recovering from his wounds. Joash was buried in Jerusalem, but not in the royal tombs.

26.verse: Joash was severely wounded during the battle, and as soon as the Syrians left Judah, two of his officials, Zabad and Jehozabad, decided to revenge the death of Zechariah. They plotted and killed Joash while he was in bed, recovering from his wounds. Joash was buried in Jerusalem, but not in the royal tombs.

27.verse: The History of the Kings also tells more about the sons of Joash, what the prophets said about him, and how he repaired the temple. Amaziah son of Joash became king after his father’s death.

1.verse: King Amaziah of Judah - Amaziah was twenty-five years old when he became king, and he ruled twenty-nine years from Jerusalem, the hometown of his mother Jehoaddin.

2.verse: Even though Amaziah obeyed the LORD by doing right, he refused to be completely faithful.

3.verse: For example, as soon as he had control of Judah, he arrested and killed the officers who had murdered his father.

4.verse: But the children of those officers were not killed; the LORD had commanded in the Law of Moses that only the people who sinned were to be punished.

5.verse: Edom Is Defeated - Amaziah sent a message to the tribes of Judah and Benjamin and called together all the men who were twenty years old and older. Three hundred thousand men went to Jerusalem, all of them ready for battle and able to fight with spears and shields. Amaziah grouped these soldiers according to their clans and put them under the command of his army officers.

6.verse: Amaziah also paid almost four tons of silver to hire one hundred thousand soldiers from Israel.

7.verse: One of God’s prophets said, “Your Majesty, don’t let these Israelite soldiers march into battle with you. The LORD has refused to help anyone from the northern kingdom of Israel,

8.verse: and so he will let your enemies defeat you, even if you fight hard. He is the one who brings both victory and defeat.”

9.verse: Amaziah replied, “What am I supposed to do about all the silver I paid those troops?” “The LORD will give you back even more than you paid,” the prophet answered.

10.verse: Amaziah ordered the troops from Israel to go home, but when they left, they were furious with the people of Judah.

11.verse: After Amaziah got his courage back, he led his troops to Salt Valley, where he killed ten thousand Edomite soldiers in battle.

12.verse: He captured ten thousand more soldiers and dragged them to the top of a high cliff. Then he pushed them over the side, and they all were killed on the rocks below.

13.verse: Meanwhile, the Israelite troops that Amaziah had sent home, raided the towns in Judah between Samaria and Beth-Horon. They killed three thousand people and carried off their possessions.

14.verse: After Amaziah had defeated the Edomite army, he returned to Jerusalem. He took with him the idols of the Edomite gods and set them up. Then he bowed down and offered them sacrifices.

15.verse: This made the LORD very angry, and he sent a prophet to ask Amaziah, “Why would you worship these foreign gods that couldn’t even save their own people from your attack?”

16.verse: But before the prophet finished speaking, Amaziah interrupted and said, “You’re not one of my advisors! Don’t say another word, or I’ll have you killed.” The prophet stopped. But then he added, “First you sinned and now you’ve ignored my warning. It’s clear that God has decided to punish you!”

17.verse: Israel Defeats Judah - King Amaziah of Judah talked with his officials, then sent a message to King Jehoash of Israel: “Come out and face me in battle!”

18.verse: Jehoash sent back a reply that said: Once upon a time, a small thornbush in Lebanon arranged the marriage between his son and the daughter of a large cedar tree. But a wild animal came along and trampled the small bush.

19.verse: Amaziah, you think you’re so powerful because you defeated Edom. But stay at home and do your celebrating. If you cause any trouble, both you and your kingdom of Judah will be destroyed.

20.verse: God made Amaziah stubborn because he was planning to punish him for worshiping the Edomite gods. Amaziah refused to listen to Jehoash’s warning,

21.verse: so Jehoash led his army to the town of Beth-Shemesh in Judah to attack Amaziah and his troops.

22.verse: During the battle, Judah’s army was crushed. Every soldier from Judah ran back home,

23.verse: and Jehoash captured Amaziah. Jehoash took Amaziah with him when he went to attack Jerusalem. Jehoash broke down the city wall from Ephraim Gate to Corner Gate, a section about six hundred feet long.

24.verse: He carried away the gold, the silver, and all the valuable furnishings from God’s temple where the descendants of Obed-Edom stood guard. He robbed the king’s treasury, took hostages, then returned to Samaria.

25.verse: Amaziah Is Killed - Amaziah lived fifteen years after Jehoash died.

26.verse: Everything else Amaziah did while he was king is written in The History of the Kings of Judah and Israel.

27.verse: As soon as Amaziah started disobeying the LORD, some people in Jerusalem plotted against Amaziah. He was able to escape to the town of Lachish, but another group of people caught him and killed him there.

28.verse: His body was taken to Jerusalem on horseback and buried beside his ancestors.

1.verse: King Uzziah of Judah - After the death of King Amaziah, the people of Judah crowned his son Uzziah king, even though he was only sixteen at the time. Uzziah ruled fifty-two years from Jerusalem, the hometown of his mother Jecoliah. During his rule, he recaptured and rebuilt the town of Elath.

2.verse: King Uzziah of Judah - After the death of King Amaziah, the people of Judah crowned his son Uzziah king, even though he was only sixteen at the time. Uzziah ruled fifty-two years from Jerusalem, the hometown of his mother Jecoliah. During his rule, he recaptured and rebuilt the town of Elath.

3.verse: King Uzziah of Judah - After the death of King Amaziah, the people of Judah crowned his son Uzziah king, even though he was only sixteen at the time. Uzziah ruled fifty-two years from Jerusalem, the hometown of his mother Jecoliah. During his rule, he recaptured and rebuilt the town of Elath.

4.verse: He obeyed the LORD by doing right, as his father Amaziah had done.

5.verse: Zechariah was Uzziah’s advisor and taught him to obey God. And so, as long as Zechariah was alive, Uzziah was faithful to God, and God made him successful.

6.verse: While Uzziah was king, he started a war against the Philistines. He smashed the walls of the cities of Gath, Jabneh, and Ashdod, then rebuilt towns around Ashdod and in other parts of Philistia.

7.verse: God helped him defeat the Philistines, the Arabs living in Gur-Baal, and the Meunites.

8.verse: Even the Ammonites paid taxes to Uzziah. He became very powerful, and people who lived as far away as Egypt heard about him.

9.verse: In Jerusalem, Uzziah built fortified towers at the Corner Gate, the Valley Gate, and the place where the city wall turned inward.

10.verse: He also built defense towers out in the desert. He owned such a large herd of livestock in the western foothills and in the flatlands, that he had cisterns dug there to catch the rainwater. He loved farming, so he had crops and vineyards planted in the hill country wherever there was fertile soil, and he hired farmers to take care of them.

11.verse: Uzziah’s army was always ready for battle. Jeiel and Maaseiah were the officers who kept track of the number of soldiers, and these two men were under the command of Hananiah, one of Uzziah’s officials.

12.verse: There were 307,500 trained soldiers, all under the command of 2,600 clan leaders. These powerful troops protected the king against any enemy.

13.verse: There were 307,500 trained soldiers, all under the command of 2,600 clan leaders. These powerful troops protected the king against any enemy.

14.verse: Uzziah supplied his army with shields, spears, helmets, armor, bows, and stones used for slinging.

15.verse: Some of his skilled workers invented machines that could shoot arrows and sling large stones. Uzziah set these up in Jerusalem at his defense towers and at the corners of the city wall. God helped Uzziah become more and more powerful, and he was famous all over the world.

16.verse: Uzziah Becomes Too Proud - Uzziah became proud of his power, and this led to his downfall. One day, Uzziah disobeyed the LORD his God by going into the temple and burning incense as an offering to him.

17.verse: Azariah the priest and eighty other brave priests followed Uzziah into the temple

18.verse: and said, “Your Majesty, this isn’t right! You are not allowed to burn incense to the LORD. That must be done only by priests who are descendants of Aaron. You will have to leave! You have sinned against the LORD, and so he will no longer bless you.”

19.verse: Uzziah, who was standing next to the incense altar at the time, was holding the incense burner, ready to offer incense to the LORD. He became very angry when he heard Azariah’s warning, and leprosy suddenly appeared on his forehead!

20.verse: Azariah and the other priests saw it and immediately told him to leave the temple. Uzziah realized that the LORD had punished him, so he hurried to get outside.

21.verse: Uzziah had leprosy the rest of his life. He was no longer allowed in the temple or in his own palace. That’s why his son Jotham lived there and ruled in his place.

22.verse: Everything else Uzziah did while he was king is in the records written by the prophet Isaiah son of Amoz.

23.verse: Since Uzziah had leprosy, he could not be buried in the royal tombs. Instead, he was buried in a nearby cemetery that the kings owned. His son Jotham then became king.

1.verse: King Jotham of Judah - Jotham was twenty-five years old when he became king of Judah, and he ruled from Jerusalem for sixteen years. Jerushah his mother was the daughter of Zadok.

2.verse: Jotham obeyed the LORD and did right. He followed the example of his father Uzziah, except he never burned incense in the temple as his father had done. But the people of Judah kept sinning against the LORD.

3.verse: Jotham rebuilt the Upper Gate of the temple and did a lot of work to repair the wall near Mount Ophel.

4.verse: He built towns in the mountains of Judah and built fortresses and defense towers in the forests.

5.verse: During his rule he attacked and defeated the Ammonites. Then every year for the next three years, he forced them to pay four tons of silver, sixty thousand bushels of wheat, and sixty thousand bushels of barley.

6.verse: Jotham remained faithful to the LORD his God and became a very powerful king.

7.verse: Everything else Jotham did while he was king, including the wars he fought, is written in The History of the Kings of Israel and Judah.

8.verse: After he had ruled Judah sixteen years, he died at the age of forty-one.

9.verse: He was buried in Jerusalem, and his son Ahaz became king.

1.verse: King Ahaz of Judah - Ahaz was twenty years old when he became king of Judah, and he ruled from Jerusalem for sixteen years. Ahaz was nothing like his ancestor David. Ahaz disobeyed the LORD

2.verse: and was as sinful as the kings of Israel. He made idols of the god Baal,

3.verse: and he offered sacrifices in Hinnom Valley. Worst of all, Ahaz sacrificed his own sons, which was a disgusting custom of the nations that the LORD had forced out of Israel.

4.verse: Ahaz offered sacrifices at the local shrines, as well as on every hill and in the shade of large trees.

5.verse: Syria and Israel Attack Judah - Ahaz and the people of Judah sinned and turned away from the LORD, the God their ancestors had worshiped. So the LORD punished them by letting their enemies defeat them. The king of Syria attacked Judah and took many of its people to Damascus as prisoners. King Pekah of Israel later defeated Judah and killed one hundred twenty thousand of its bravest soldiers in one day.

6.verse: Syria and Israel Attack Judah - Ahaz and the people of Judah sinned and turned away from the LORD, the God their ancestors had worshiped. So the LORD punished them by letting their enemies defeat them. The king of Syria attacked Judah and took many of its people to Damascus as prisoners. King Pekah of Israel later defeated Judah and killed one hundred twenty thousand of its bravest soldiers in one day.

7.verse: During that battle, an Israelite soldier named Zichri killed three men from Judah: Maaseiah the king’s son; Azrikam, the official in charge of the palace; and Elkanah, the king’s second in command.

8.verse: The Israelite troops captured two hundred thousand women and children and took them back to their capital city of Samaria, along with a large amount of their possessions. They did these things even though the people of Judah were their own relatives.

9.verse: Oded the Prophet Condemns Israel - Oded lived in Samaria and was one of the LORD’s prophets. He met Israel’s army on their way back from Judah and said to them: The LORD God of your ancestors let you defeat Judah’s army only because he was angry with them. But you should not have been so cruel!

10.verse: If you make slaves of the people of Judah and Jerusalem, you will be as guilty as they are of sinning against the LORD.

11.verse: Send these prisoners back home—they are your own relatives. If you don’t, the LORD will punish you in his anger.

12.verse: About the same time, four of Israel’s leaders arrived. They were Azariah son of Johanan, Berechiah son of Meshillemoth, Jehizkiah son of Shallum, and Amasa son of Hadlai. They agreed with Oded that the Israelite troops were wrong,

13.verse: and they said: If you bring these prisoners into Samaria, that will be one more thing we’ve done to sin against the LORD. And he is already angry enough at us.

14.verse: So in front of the leaders and the crowd, the troops handed over their prisoners and the property they had taken from Judah.

15.verse: The four leaders took some of the stolen clothes and gave them to the prisoners who needed something to wear. They later gave them all a new change of clothes and shoes, then fixed them something to eat and drink, and cleaned their wounds with olive oil. They gave donkeys to those who were too weak to walk, and led all of them back to Jericho, the city known for its palm trees. The leaders then returned to Samaria.

And at the same time, the Philistines raided towns in the western foothills and in the Southern Desert. They conquered the towns of Beth-Shemesh, Aijalon, Gederoth, Soco, Timnah, and Gimzo, including the villages around them. Then some of the Philistines went to live in these places. Ahaz sent a message to King Tiglath Pileser of Assyria and begged for help.

And at the same time, the Philistines raided towns in the western foothills and in the Southern Desert. They conquered the towns of Beth-Shemesh, Aijalon, Gederoth, Soco, Timnah, and Gimzo, including the villages around them. Then some of the Philistines went to live in these places. Ahaz sent a message to King Tiglath Pileser of Assyria and begged for help.

19.verse: But God was punishing Judah with these disasters, because Ahaz had disobeyed him and refused to stop Judah from sinning.

20.verse: So Tiglath Pileser came to Judah, but instead of helping, he made things worse.

21.verse: Ahaz gave him gifts from the LORD’s temple and the king’s palace, as well as from the homes of Israel’s other leaders. The Assyrian king still refused to help Ahaz.

22.verse: The Final Sin of Ahaz and His Death - Even after all these terrible things happened to Ahaz, he sinned against the LORD even worse than before.

23.verse: He said to himself, “The Syrian gods must have helped their kings defeat me. Maybe if I offer sacrifices to those gods, they will help me.” That was the sin that finally led to the downfall of Ahaz, as well as to the destruction of Judah.

24.verse: Ahaz collected all the furnishings of the temple and smashed them to pieces. Then he locked the doors to the temple and set up altars to foreign gods on every street corner in Jerusalem.

25.verse: In every city and town in Judah he built local shrines to worship foreign gods. All of this made the LORD God of his ancestors very angry.

26.verse: Everything else Ahaz did while he was king is written in The History of the Kings of Judah and Israel.

27.verse: Ahaz died and was buried in Jerusalem, but not in the royal tombs. His son Hezekiah then became king.

1.verse: King Hezekiah of Judah - Hezekiah was twenty-five years old when he became king of Judah, and he ruled twenty-nine years from Jerusalem. His mother was Abijah daughter of Zechariah.

2.verse: Hezekiah obeyed the LORD by doing right, just as his ancestor David had done.

3.verse: The Temple Is Purified - In the first month of the first year of Hezekiah’s rule, he unlocked the doors to the LORD’s temple and had them repaired.

4.verse: Then he called the priests and Levites to the east courtyard of the temple

5.verse: and said: It’s time to purify the temple of the LORD God of our ancestors. You Levites must first go through the ceremony to make yourselves clean, then go into the temple and bring out everything that is unclean and unacceptable to the LORD.

6.verse: Some of our ancestors were unfaithful and disobeyed the LORD our God. Not only did they turn their backs on the LORD, but they also completely ignored his temple.

7.verse: They locked the doors, then let the lamps go out and stopped burning incense and offering sacrifices to him.

8.verse: The LORD became terribly angry at the people of Judah and Jerusalem, and everyone was shocked and horrified at what he did to punish them. Not only were

9.verse: our ancestors killed in battle, but our own children and wives were taken captive.

10.verse: So I have decided to renew our agreement with the LORD God of Israel. Maybe then he will stop being so angry at us.

11.verse: Let’s not waste any time, my friends. You are the ones who were chosen to be the LORD’s priests and to offer him sacrifices.

12.verse: When Hezekiah finished talking, the following Levite leaders went to work: Mahath son of Amasai and Joel son of Azariah from the Kohath clan; Kish son of Abdi and Azariah son of Jehallelel from the Merari clan; Joah son of Zimmah and Eden son of Joah from the Gershon clan; Shimri and Jeuel from the Elizaphan clan; Zechariah and Mattaniah from the Asaph clan; Jehuel and Shimei from the Heman clan; Shemaiah and Uzziel from the Jeduthun clan.

15.verse: These leaders gathered together the rest of the Levites, and they all went through the ceremony to make themselves clean. Then they began to purify the temple according to the Law of the LORD, just as Hezekiah had commanded.

16.verse: The priests went into the temple and carried out everything that was unclean. They put these things in the courtyard, and from there, the Levites carried them outside the city to Kidron Valley.

17.verse: The priests and Levites began their work on the first day of the first month. It took them one week to purify the courtyards of the temple and another week to purify the temple. So on the sixteenth day of that same month

18.verse: they went back to Hezekiah and said: Your Majesty, we have finished our work. The entire temple is now pure again, and so is the altar and its utensils, as well as the table for the sacred loaves of bread and its utensils.

19.verse: And we have brought back all the things that King Ahaz took from the temple during the time he was unfaithful to God. We purified them and put them back in front of the altar.

20.verse: Worship in the Temple - Right away, Hezekiah called together the officials of Jerusalem, and they went to the temple.

21.verse: They brought with them seven bulls, seven rams, seven lambs, and seven goats as sacrifices to take away the sins of Hezekiah’s family and of the people of Judah, as well as to purify the temple. Hezekiah told the priests, who were descendants of Aaron, to sacrifice these animals on the altar.

22.verse: The priests killed the bulls, the rams, and the lambs, then splattered the blood on the altar.

23.verse: They took the goats to Hezekiah and the worshipers, and they laid their hands on the animals.

24.verse: The priests then killed the goats and splattered the blood on the altar as a sacrifice to take away the sins of everyone in Israel, because Hezekiah had commanded that these sacrifices be made for all the people of Israel.

25.verse: Next, Hezekiah assigned the Levites to their places in the temple. He gave them cymbals, harps, and other stringed instruments, according to the instructions that the LORD had given King David and the two prophets, Gad and Nathan.

26.verse: The Levites were ready to play the instruments that had belonged to David; the priests were ready to blow the trumpets.

27.verse: As soon as Hezekiah gave the signal for the sacrifices to be burned on the altar, the musicians began singing praises to the LORD and playing their instruments,

28.verse: and everyone worshiped the LORD. This continued until the last animal was sacrificed.

29.verse: After that, Hezekiah and the crowd of worshipers knelt down and worshiped the LORD.

30.verse: Then Hezekiah and his officials ordered the Levites to sing the songs of praise that David and Asaph the prophet had written. And so they bowed down and joyfully sang praises to the LORD.

31.verse: Hezekiah said to the crowd, “Now that you are once again acceptable to the LORD, bring sacrifices and offerings to give him thanks.” The people did this, and some of them voluntarily brought animals to be offered as sacrifices.

32.verse: Seventy bulls, one hundred rams, and two hundred lambs were brought as sacrifices to please the LORD;

33.verse: six hundred bulls and three thousand sheep were brought as sacrifices to ask the LORD’s blessing.

34.verse: There were not enough priests to skin all these animals, because many of the priests had not taken the time to go through the ceremony to make themselves clean. However, since all the Levites had made themselves clean, they helped the priests until the last animal was skinned.

35.verse: Besides all the sacrifices that were burned on the altar, the fat from the other animal sacrifices was burned, and the offerings of wine were poured over the altar. So the temple was once again used for worshiping the LORD.

36.verse: Hezekiah and the people of Judah celebrated, because God had helped them make this happen so quickly.

So Hezekiah, his officials, and the people agreed to celebrate Passover in the second month. Hezekiah sent a message to everyone in Israel and Judah, including those in the territories of Ephraim and West Manasseh, inviting them to the temple in Jerusalem for the celebration of Passover in honor of the LORD God of Israel.

5.verse: Everyone from Beersheba in the south to Dan in the north was invited. This was the largest crowd of people that had ever celebrated Passover, according to the official records.

6.verse: Hezekiah’s messengers went everywhere in Israel and Judah with the following letter: People of Israel, now that you have survived the invasion of the Assyrian kings, it’s time for you to turn back to the LORD God our ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob worshiped. If you do this, he will stop being angry.

7.verse: Don’t follow the example of your ancestors and your Israelite relatives in the north. They were unfaithful to the LORD, and he punished them horribly.

8.verse: Don’t be stubborn like your ancestors. Decide now to obey the LORD our God! Come to Jerusalem and worship him in the temple that will belong to him forever. Then he will stop being angry,

9.verse: and the enemies that have captured your families will show pity and send them back home. The LORD God is kind and merciful, and if you turn back to him, he will no longer turn his back on you.

10.verse: The messengers went to every town in Ephraim and West Manasseh as far north as the territory of Zebulun, but everyone laughed and insulted them.

11.verse: Only a few people from the tribes of Asher, West Manasseh, and Zebulun were humble and went to Jerusalem.

12.verse: God also made everyone in Judah eager to do what Hezekiah and his officials had commanded.

13.verse: Passover Is Celebrated - In the second month, a large crowd of people gathered in Jerusalem to celebrate the Festival of Thin Bread.

14.verse: They took all the foreign altars and incense altars in Jerusalem and threw them into Kidron Valley.

15.verse: Then, on the fourteenth day of that same month, the Levites began killing the lambs for Passover, because many of the worshipers were unclean and were not allowed to kill their own lambs. Meanwhile, some of the priests and Levites felt ashamed because they had not gone through the ceremony to make themselves clean. They immediately went through that ceremony and went to the temple, where they offered sacrifices to please the LORD. Then the priests and Levites took their positions, according to the Law of Moses, the servant of God. As the Levites killed the lambs, they handed some of the blood to the priests, who splattered it on the altar.

Hezekiah found out what they had done and prayed, “LORD God, these people are unclean according to the laws of holiness. But they are worshiping you, just as their ancestors did. 20.verse: The LORD answered Hezekiah’s prayer and did not punish them.

21.verse: The worshipers in Jerusalem were very happy and celebrated the Festival for seven days. The Levites and priests sang praises to the LORD every day and played their instruments.

22.verse: Hezekiah thanked the Levites for doing such a good job, leading the celebration. The worshipers celebrated for seven days by offering sacrifices, by eating the sacred meals, and by praising the LORD God of their ancestors.

23.verse: Everyone was so excited that they agreed to celebrate seven more days.

24.verse: So Hezekiah gave the people one thousand bulls and seven thousand sheep to be offered as sacrifices and to be used as food for the sacred meals. His officials gave one thousand bulls and ten thousand sheep, and many more priests agreed to go through the ceremony to make themselves clean.

25.verse: Everyone was very happy, including those from Judah and Israel, the priests and Levites, and the foreigners living in Judah and Israel.

26.verse: It was the biggest celebration in Jerusalem since the days of King Solomon, the son of David.

27.verse: The priests and Levites asked God to bless the people, and from his home in heaven, he did.

1.verse: The People Destroy the Local Shrines - After the Festival, the people went to every town in Judah and smashed the stone images of foreign gods and cut down the sacred poles for worshiping the goddess Asherah. They destroyed all the local shrines and foreign altars in Judah, as well as those in the territories of Benjamin, Ephraim, and West Manasseh. Then everyone went home.

2.verse: Offerings for the Priests and Levites - Hezekiah divided the priests and Levites into groups, according to their duties. Then he assigned them the responsibilities of offering sacrifices to please the LORD and sacrifices to ask his blessing. He also appointed people to serve at the temple and to sing praises at the temple gates.

3.verse: Hezekiah provided animals from his own herds and flocks to use for the morning and evening sacrifices, as well as for the sacrifices during the Sabbath celebrations, the New Moon Festivals, and the other religious feasts required by the Law of the LORD.

4.verse: He told the people of Jerusalem to bring the offerings that were to be given to the priests and Levites, so that they would have time to serve the LORD with their work.

5.verse: As soon as the people heard what the king wanted, they brought a tenth of everything they owned, including their best grain, wine, olive oil, honey, and other crops.

6.verse: The people from the other towns of Judah brought a tenth of their herds and flocks, as well as a tenth of anything they had dedicated to the LORD.

7.verse: The people started bringing their offerings to Jerusalem in the third month, and the last ones arrived four months later.

8.verse: When Hezekiah and his officials saw these offerings, they thanked the LORD and the people.

9.verse: Hezekiah asked the priests and Levites about the large amount of offerings.

10.verse: The high priest at the time was Azariah, a descendant of Zadok, and he replied, “Ever since the people have been bringing us their offerings, we have had more than enough food and supplies. The LORD has certainly blessed his people. Look at how much is left over!”

11.verse: So the king gave orders for storerooms to be built in the temple, and when they were completed,

12.verse: all the extra offerings were taken there. Hezekiah and Azariah then appointed Conaniah the Levite to be in charge of these storerooms. His brother Shimei was his assistant, and the following Levites worked with them: Jehiel, Azaziah, Nahath, Asahel, Jerimoth, Jozabad, Eliel, Ismachiah, Mahath, and Benaiah.

19.verse: Hezekiah also appointed other men to take food and supplies to the priests and Levites whose homes were in the pastureland around the towns of Judah. But the priests had to be descendants of Aaron, and the Levites had to be listed in the official records.
